document.docAuthor: Khaustov, Alexander A., Hugo-Coetzee, Elizabeth A., Ermilov, Sergey G. & Theron, Pieter D.
document.docTitle: Sidorchukdispus ekaterinae Khaustov & Hugo-Coetzee & Ermilov & Theron 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new genus and species of the family Microdispidae (Acari: Heterostigmata) associated with Trinervitermes trinervoides (Sjöstedt) (Isoptera: Termitidae) from South Africa

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus and species of the family Microdispidae (Acari: Heterostigmata) associated with Trinervitermes trinervoides (Sjöstedt) (Isoptera: Termitidae) from South Africa

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. FEMALE ( Figs 1–8 ). Length of idiosoma 150 (140–160), width 80 (80–85).

Gnathosoma ( Figs 2 , 5 , 6E, F , 7C ). Length of gnathosoma 16 (16–18), width 15 (14–15). Dorsal median apodeme absent. Length of cheliceral stylets: 12 (11–13). All gnathosomal setae needle-like and smooth. Lengths of gnathosomal setae cha 5 (5), chb 5 (5), pp 3 (3), m 6 (5–6), dFe 4 (4), dGe 5 (4–5). Pharyngeal pumps as in figure 2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3 .
Sidorchukdispus ekaterinae
gen., sp. nov. , female: A—left leg I in dorsal view, B—Left leg II in dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Idiosomal venter ( Figs 1B , 7A, B ). Aggenital and posterior part of posterior sternal plates with scale-like microsculpture. All ventral setae pointed. Setae 1 b , ps 1 , and ps 3 distinctly barbed, other ventral setae smooth. Lateral plates with several oblique sclerotized lines laterally to legs III–IV. Posterior margin of aggenital plate evenly rounded. Lengths of ventral setae: 1 a 17 (17–19), 1 b 17 (17–20), 2 a 25 (24–27), 2 b 22 (21–23), 3 a 19 (18–21), 3 b 23 (21–23), 3 c 18 (17–18), 4 a 25 (24–26), 4 b 30 (28–31), 4 c 25 (24–26), ps 1 22 (21–23), ps 3 19 (19–20).

Legs ( Figs 3 , 4 , 7 D-F). Leg I ( Fig. 3A ). Lengths of solenidia ω 1 8 (8–9), φ 1 5 (5), φ 2 7 (7–8); ω 1 large, fingershaped, φ 1 clavate, φ 2 baculiform. Setae v’ of trochanter, v” of femur, l” of genu, k , pl” and ( pv ) of tibiotarsus smooth; other setae (except eupathidia) barbed. Setae l’ of femur and ( l ) of genu blunt-ended; other setae (except eupathidia) pointed. Leg II ( Figs 3B , 7E ). Solenidion ω 5 (5) prominent, finger-shaped, solenidion φ 3 (3) ( Fig. 7E ) weakly clavate, located in depression. Setae d of femur and tibia weakly blunt-ended, other setae pointed. Setae v’ of trochanter, l’ , v” of femur, v’ of genu, l’ of tibia, pl” , tc” and pv” of tarsus smooth; other setae barbed. Seta v” of femur very small, 1–2 long. Leg III ( Figs 4A , 7F ). Solenidion ω 5 (5) prominent, finger-shaped, solenidion φ 2 (2) weakly clavate, located in depression ( Fig. 7F ). Seta d of femur weakly blunt-ended, other setae pointed. Setae tc’ and pv” of tarsus smooth; other setae barbed. Leg IV ( Fig. 4B ). Setae v” of tibia and tc’ of tarsus smooth, other setae barbed. Seta v’ of trochanter, d of femur and tibia blunt-ended, other setae pointed. Tibia IV without solenidia, but with pore-like structure visible on its typical insertion point.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4 .
Sidorchukdispus ekaterinae
gen., sp. nov. , female: A—left leg III in dorsal view, B—Left leg IV in dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. Female
holotype , slide
VK 161018
, South Africa , North West Province , near Potchefstroom , Faan Meintjes Nature Reserve , 26°42’S 26°42’E , on termites
Trinervitermes trinervoides (Sjöstedt)
,
16 October 2018
, collected by
V.A. Khaustov
, S.G. Ermilov
;
paratypes : 36 females , same data
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 . DIC micrographs of
Sidorchukdispus ekaterinae
gen., sp. nov. , female: A—gnathosoma in dorsal view, B—gnathosoma in ventral view. St—cheliceral stylets, lev—levers of cheliceral stylets.

subSubSection.paragraph: Type deposition. The holotype and 10 paratypes are deposited in the acarological collection of the National Museum, Bloemfontein, South Africa ( NMBS ), other paratypes are deposited in the mite collection of the Tyumen State University Museum of Zoology, Tyumen , Russia ( TSUMZ )— Zhang (2018) . Etymology. The new species is named after the late Dr Ekaterina Sidorchuk.
